Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: High Resolution EEG Signal Analysis for Seizure Detection and Treatment

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The investigators have developed flexible, active, multiplexed recording devices to enable interface with thousands of electrodes implanted on the surface of the brain. While this technology has enabled a much finer view of the electrical activity of the brain, the analytical methods to process, categorize and respond to the huge volumes of data produced by these devices are presently lacking. Many existing neurological data analyses rely on manual inspection. With new neural interfaces with thousands of channels, the data volume is infeasible for manual review. Further, manual inspection can miss subtle features that automated machine learning techniques can detect. In this research, the investigators develop efficient and sensitive automated methods to analyze micro-electrocorticographic (ÂµECoG) data from patients with epilepsy. These methods are used to segment, categorize and predict spatiotemporal epileptiform discharge (or spike) patterns. Understanding the ordering and relationships between these patterns is a key to developing better seizure detection and prediction techniques and ultimately better therapies for patients with epilepsy.

This research comprises four interconnected components. The first component develops techniques for detecting and isolating spike segments, and for extracting features that capture the spatio-temporal pattern of each spike. The second component develops unsupervised clustering algorithms that can identify distinct clusters of spike motion patterns based on carefully chosen features. The thir-d component develops classifiers that can categorize each spike into a few classes (inter-ical, pre-ictal, ictal and post-ictal) based on not only its spatio-temporal pattern, but also the patterns of past spikes. The final component develops methods to predict spike wavefront locations. The combination of these methods will enable seizure prediction and real-time responsive brain stimulation to suppress seizures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Recent improvements in microfabrication have enabled the development of high resolution neural recording devices (known as micro-ECoG) that can cover large, clinically relevant areas of the brain. One major application of such devices is to record and examine brain signals in patients with epilepsy. However, these new devices can record from thousands of individual sensors on the brain, making manual review by clinicians impossible. There is a critical need for computational algorithms that can efficiently analyze and “make sense” of the huge amount of recorded data. These new analytical tools can lead to a new clinical understanding and new treatments for epilepsy.  This project has developed algorithms for detecting and isolating electrographic spike segments and prototypical spike patterns with different motion characteristics during seizures. The project also developed a method that can accurately detect and predict the onset of seizures shortly before they start. Furthermore, we have developed several methods that can accurately predict future micro-ECoG data from past observations. This kind of prediction can have potential clinical applications, such as developing real-time stimulation to suppress seizures. These algorithms were developed and validated using in-vivo recordings of animal models of seizures. We also analyzed limited micro-ECoG recordings we have collected from humans. We have found that the human data are more complex and have fewer distinguishable spike patterns in the non-seizure stage. However, we are able to identify very low dimensional features from which the original data can be reconstructed, indicating that data from the electrodes could be efficiently compressed and transmitted wirelessly. Similarly, we were able to apply our data analysis methods to data collected from the heart using our high-density electrode arrays and created maps of the activation of the cardiac cycle.

We also quantified the long-term reliability and information content of the µECoG signal. We developed a new signal analysis framework to estimate the required electrode spacing to fully capture all of the information available from the surface of the brain. This result also enabled us to leverage spatial oversampling of the neural signal to improve the signal to noise ratio of the recorded signals. This will be extremely useful for future neural interface systems that can sample neural activity with practically unbounded spatial resolution, but with limited signal to noise ratio. This technique will allow us to improve the overall performance of neural interface systems. 

Intellectual merit:

Our algorithm development has contributed to both signal processing and machine learning fields.  The proposed algorithms for micro-ECoG signal prediction using multi-resolution layers integrate the idea of multi-resolution signal processing into machine learning, and are generally applicable for long-term prediction of any spatial-temporal signals. Multi-resolution layers can also be used for unsupervised feature learning and extraction for spatial-temporal signals. We were the first group to apply unsupervised deep learning framework to micro-ECoG signals, and to demonstrate the capability of predicting neural activities from past observations, and the ability to reconstruct observed signals from low-dimensional features extracted from human recordings.

Broader impacts: 

Over 1/3 of the world’s 60 million people with epilepsy (3 million in the U.S.) have seizures that cannot be controlled by medication. First generation antiepileptic devices are promising, but efficacy is modest. Epilepsy surgery outcomes (e.g. 50-59% seizure freedom) have not improved in over 20 years. We anticipate that the tools we developed will lead to a greater understanding of the microscale phenomena that give rise to seizures in patients with epilepsy, and to enable better treatment and management of seizure patients.  The techniques we have developed will also be applicable to analyzing high resolution neural data from similar electrode implants in motor prosthetic systems, deep brain stimulation and other neural prosthetic devices.

This project contributed to the training of two Ph.D. students, who have recently graduated.  They have gained invaluable research experience. Several MS and undergraduate students who assisted the Ph.D. students also gained valuable experience. 

We have published all of the data used in this project on the International Epilepsy Electrophysiology Portal (ieeg.org), where it is publicly accessible for any researcher to access.
